title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico. The study will determine the construction of potable water transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs in cooperation with state and local authorities. The study will assess the feasibility of constructing a water supply system for the Town, including potable water transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. It will consider various water supply options, reuse/recycling of water, alternative water sources, and determine the total lifecycle costs of the system. The study will assess the feasibility of constructing a water supply system for the Town, including potable water transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. It will consider reusing or recycling water from local or regional sources, using alternative water supplies, and determining the total lifecycle costs of the system. The deadline for the study is within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination with relevant agencies is required. The Secretary must complete a feasibility study within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination with relevant agencies is required, including accessing Bureau of Land Management land and drilling exploratory wells. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must complete a feasibility study within 3 years with a 75 percent Federal cost share, including drilling exploratory wells on Bureau of Land Management land. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion. Additionally, the Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area. The Secretary may enter into contracts with water authorities in the study area to provide emergency water supply development assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing purification technology, drilling wells, and more as deemed appropriate. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance for activities like installing pipelines, designing emergency systems, and other eligible activities determined by the Secretary. The Federal share of the cost for these activities shall be 75 percent. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103 for fiscal years 2005-2010. Funds under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The term "component" refers to a water delivery infrastructure development, while "facility" specifically means the Espanola water filtration facility. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Commissioner of Reclamation, is responsible for these definitions. The Secretary is tasked with providing financial assistance to the city of Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility, which includes projects to divert and utilize imported water for future needs in the region. This involves building presedimentation basins and an influent pump station for water treatment facilities. The Espanola water filtration facility project includes constructing presedimentation basins, an influent pump station, pretreatment and filtration facilities, finished water storage, booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and water transmission lines. Additionally, reclaimed water will be used to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for this project. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of water delivery infrastructure for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos in New Mexico. The Federal share of the total cost shall not exceed 25 percent, and funds cannot be used for operation or maintenance of the facility. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
